text:
Huts 9 and 10
In 1941, the Wehrmacht was planning to build 24 huts to house 20,000 POWs, but only five of them were hastily erected. Their 80-by-18-metre-long walls were made of clay bricks, and the huts were divided into five rooms. Officially, each hut had the capacity to house up to 900 prisoners. Foundation and flooring remains of two huts still exist. From April 1943, these huts were part of the concentration camp. Hut 9 was used as a depot, while hut 10 was initially used to house prisoners from the special camp. By the summer of 1944, however, a large number of these prisoners had been deported to Auschwitz-Birkenau. The SS then also housed prisoners from the Hungarians’ camp in this hut. They were kept strictly separate from the few remaining special camp prisoners. In mid-January 1945, when the men’s camp was expanded, hut 10 became part of this camp section and was completely overcrowded with male prisoners. The men, who suffered from serious diseases and malnutrition when they arrived at Bergen-Belsen, were isolated and received no food. Almost none of the prisoners in hut 10 survived.

text:
The Men's Camp
The first transport with 1,000 sick prisoners arrived in Bergen-Belsen on 27 March 1944. The evacuation transports brought people from all countries occupied by the Germans to Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. The majority of the prisoners in the camp came from Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union. The largest groups were the political prisoners and those who were persecuted based on the racist National-Socialist ideology, especially Jews, Sinti and Roma.

text:
The Star Camp
More than 5,400 prisoners were imprisoned in the so called Star Camp. The first prisoners arrived there in August 1943 from Greece, but the majority arrived between January and September 1944 from the Westerbork transit camp in the Netherlands. Most of these prisoners were Dutch Jews, but among them were also numerous German Jews who had fled the Nazis to the Netherlands. The prisoners called this camp section Star Camp because the prisoners there had to wear the yellow star.

The Gate to the Concentration Camp Prisoners' Compound
A fence with a simple gate on the camp’s main street separated the prisoners’ compound from the SS administration section of the concentration camp. Directly next to the gate in the administration section stood a hut for SS guards. A few weeks after the liberation, British soldiers put up two signs to the left and the right of the gate with admonishing inscriptions in German and English.

text:
The Hungarians' Camp
The Hungarians’ Camp was established in July 1944 for almost 1,700 Jews from Hungary. In December 1944, around 4,200 further prisoners arrived in this camp section in two transports. Prisoners here mainly stayed in their families. They were allowed to keep parts of their luggage and wore civilian clothes. The SS installed a self-administration to operate the Hungarinas' Camp. In early February 1945 the prisoners of the Hungarians' Camp were moved to huts in the area of the former Star Camp.

text:
The Star Camp's Roll-Call Square
Each of the strictly separated camp sections at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp had its own roll-call square. The SS held roll calls every day and in any kind of weather to count the thousands of prisoners. During these roll calls, prisoners had to stand to attention, usually in rows of five. Additional roll calls were also held, sometimes several times a day. The many roll calls represented a permanent physical and psychological strain for the prisoners. Particularly sick or old prisoners and children found it very hard to stand to attention for prolonged periods.

text:
The Camp's Main Street
The camp’s main street, a six-metre-wide sand track, was built in 1941 during the expansion of the POW camp. It lay at the centre of the 70-metre-wide area between the huts for POWs and those for concentration camp prisoners. This part of the camp also contained facilities such as kitchens, fire water reservoirs and food depots. The main street was under permanent watch by the guards. Camp inmates were only allowed to use it on work assignments during the day and had to be accompanied by guards.

text:
The Camp's Perimeter
From 1941, the Bergen-Belsen camp comprised an area of almost 55 hectares. It was surrounded by a 2.5-metre high barbed-wire fence with wooden poles that ran a length of nearly four kilometres and consisted of two rows in some sections. The camp’s main entrance was located near the road from Winsen to Bergen. The POW camp and the concentration camp as well as their individual camp sections were separated from each other by more fences. Watchtowers were located along the perimeter fence and inside the camp.

text:
Workshops
From late 1944 on, the SS-owned weaving and knotting works forced prisoners to produce belts, camouflage nets and similar things from leftover fabric and leather, cellophane or other scrap materials and then sold the products to their private customers. Large numbers of female prisoners from Bergen-Belsen concentration camp were forced to work at the weaving works. Before the weaving works was established, the site was used for prisoners from the exchange camp working on shoe detail. For a while, female prisoners from the exchange camp were also forced to work at the weaving works.

text:
Delousing Baths
For many POWs and concentration camp prisoners, the baths at the delousing building were the only place where they could tend to their personal hygiene. Most prisoners got to shower after their arrival, while their clothes were being deloused. After that, they were only permitted to use the baths at irregular intervals. During the last months before the liberation, prisoners were no longer allowed to use the baths at all. Delousing and showering were humiliating procedures carried out under the constant watch of the guards, and they often contributed to the spread of disease instead of preventing it.

text:
The Women's Camp
From Mid-August 1944, the SS brought female concentration camp prisoners to Bergen-Belsen. They were initially housed in tents in a provisional camp section and later in huts. As the numbers of prisoners increased, the SS gradually expanded the women’s camp. Many of the female prisoners were sent to satellite camps of other concentration camps to perform slave labour. However, the number of sick and weakened women who remained in Bergen-Belsen continued to grow. From mid-January 1945, the SS used the huts of the dissolved POW hospital for the concentration camp and housed part of the women’s camp there.

text:
Cemetery and Post-War landscape
Today, the cemetery in the grounds of the former camp contains 15 individual and 13 mass graves. In September 1945, Jewish survivors unveiled a monument which they replaced in 1946 with the Jewish monument that still stands today. Polish survivors put up a large wooden cross to commemorate the camp’s Polish victims in November 1945. There are also more than 100 memorial stones in the cemetery which were put up by relatives or friends of victims. In October 1945, the British military government ordered a memorial to be established at the site. The Bergen-Belsen Memorial with its obelisk and inscription wall was officially opened in 1952.

text:
Prisoners of the Polish Home Army (Armia Krajowa)
In October 1944, ten huts were blocked off from the POW camp. Around 1,000 soldiers of the Polish Home Army (Armia Krajowa) were housed in this compound until mid-January 1945. They had fought against the German occupiers in the Warsaw Uprising. Almost half of these soldiers were women. The Wehrmacht treated the Home Army prisoners according to the 1929 Geneva Convention. This made it possible for inspectors from the International Committee of the Red Cross to visit this camp section in November 1944. In their report, they mainly criticized the insufficient rations, medication and clothes the prisoners were given.

text:
Italian Military Internees
Between July 1944 and mid-January 1945, around 800 Italian military internees were treated there. The Italian prisoners were generally regarded as traitors by the Nazi leadership, the Wehrmacht and large parts of the German population. After their capture, they were deported to Germany for forced labour. Because of the insufficient food they received and the maltreatment they were subjected to at the hands of their guards, many of them had to be treated at POW hospitals like the one at Bergen-Belsen. The hospital, however, did not have enough medical supplies or food, and the sanitary conditions were disastrous. 142 Italian military internees died at Bergen-Belsen. They were buried at the nearby POW cemetery.

text:
The concentration Camp, Introduction
The Bergen-Belsen concentration camp was part of the official concentration camp system from the time it was established in April 1943. Today, many consider it the embodiment of Nazi crimes. However, Bergen-Belsen differed from all other Nazi concentration camps in several key aspects. Bergen-Belsen was initially set up for Jewish hostages whom the SS had said they would release - in exchange for Germans interned abroad, foreign currency or commodities valuable to the war effort. The character of the camp changed in March 1944 when a new section was established for sick male prisoners from other concentration camps who were no longer able to work. A section for female prisoners was set up in August 1944. In December 1944, the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp became the destination for numerous evacuation transports from other concentration camps. The camp’s subsequent overcrowding and disastrous living conditions led to mass deaths which claimed the lives of around 18,000 victims in March 1945 alone. At least 52,000 of the total of around 120,000 prisoners in Bergen-Belsen died of starvation or disease, of the abuse they received from the SS, or of the immediate effects of their imprisonment following their liberation.

text:
The POW camp, Introduction
From 1940, the huts of the former construction workers’ camp were used to house 600 French and Belgian POWs. Starting in May 1941, it was transformed into an independent camp known as Stalag XI C which was intended to hold 20,000 Soviet POWs. Two other so-called “Russian camps” were set up nearby at Oerbke and at Wietzendorf. Around 41,000 Soviet POWs had died in these camps of starvation, exhaustion and disease by the end of March 1942, and a total of 50,000 Soviet POWs died there by the end of the war. Stalag XI C was disbanded in the summer of 1943, and Bergen-Belsen became a branch camp of Stalag XI B at Fallingbostel. It remained in operation as the central hospital for Soviet POWs in the region until January 1945. Italian military internees were treated there as well from August 1944. After the suppression of the Warsaw Uprising in October 1944, around 1,000 members of the Polish Home Army were also housed in a separate section of the POW camp.

Neutrals' Camp
From August 1943, around 600 prisoners were taken to the Neutrals’ Camp. They were citizens of Spain, Portugal and Turkey, countries that were neutral during WWII. The SS and the German Foreign Office planned to release and repatriate them.

text:
Special Camp for Jews from Poland
From July 1943, around 2700 Jews from Poland were transported to the Special Camp. Many of them had passports from Southamerican countries or so called Promesas. Others held British Palestinian Certificates. Between October 1943 and May 1944 the SS deported most of them - more than 2000 people - to Auschwitz and murdered them.

text:
Soviet Prisoners of War
Around 21,000 Soviet POWs were taken to the Bergen-Belsen Stalag (POW camp) between July and December 1941. The Nazis were planning to use them as slave labourers. During the first months, the main camp was only a compound with a barbed-wire fence and some watchtowers. There were almost no huts to house the prisoners, who had to dig earthwork dens to protect themselves from the elements. The rations they were given were not enough to sustain them, and hygiene conditions were disastrous. The Wehrmacht consistently ignored important sections of the 1929 Geneva Convention. In June 1943, the main camp was officially dissolved. Most of the prisoners had been transferred elsewhere for slave labour by then, and the SS had taken over the empty camp section in April 1943.

text:
Perpetrators
The Wehrmacht was responsible for housing, feeding and guarding the POWs. The POWs were guarded by soldiers who could not be deployed to the front because of their age or physical afflications. The camps' headquarters were staffed with reserve officers, many of whom were over 60 years old and had already served in World War I. The guidelines for the conduct towards Soviet POWs issued by the Wehrmacht High Command demanded a ruthless treatment of these prisoners without any respect for martial or international law. Many soldiers acted accordingly, others sometimes used the leeway they had to the to prisoners advantage.

The first guards squads to be deployed at Bergen-Belsen exchange camp came from the recently disbanded Niederhagen concentration camp. Niederhagen's commandant, SS-Sturmbannführer Adolf Haas, became the first commandant of Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. In July 1943, the commandant of the Theresienstadt ghetto, SS-Hauptsturmführer Dr Siegfird Seidl, was transferred to Bergn-Belsen. As head of the political department, he was in charge of the exchange prisoners. In December 1944, SS-Hauptsturmführer Josef Kramer replaced Haas as commandant. Prior to this, Kramer had been commandant of the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp. He also brought female SS guards to Bergen-Belsen for the first time. Between April 1943 and April 1945, at least 480 SS guards were posted to Bergen-Belsen, among them around 45 female guards.

text:
Death and dying
Hunger and disease were the main death causes of the mass deaths that occurred in Bergen-Belsen.  The exact number of people who died at the Bergen-Belsen POW and concentration camps is difficult to establish. Almost 20,000 prisoners died at the POW camp. The Wehrmacht had their bodies buried in a cemetery located 600 metres away from the camp. At least 52,000 people died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Many of the dead were buried in mass graves in the grounds of the former camp following the liberation. Another cemetery is located at the Belsen barracks. So far, only 10,000 victims of the concentration camp are known by name. Today, the cemetery in the grounds of the former camp contains 15 individual and 13 mass graves.

Gate to the Prisoner Compound
Between 1941 and 1943, the camp section close to the road contained the POW camp’s entrance section with the guard hut, stores, workshops, the “arrival pen” for newly arrived prisoners, the disinfection building, the camp prison and other facilities. The POW camp’s headquarters were located at the Belsen barracks. The entrance section also contained the so-called “special pen” where Soviet POWs who had been identified as Jews or communist functionaries were kept before being transported to the Sachsenhausen concentration camp and murdered. In April 1943, the entrance section passed from the Wehrmacht to the SS, and the concentration camp administration was housed there. Some of the facilities, like the disinfection building, were then also used by both camps.

text:
Watchtower, Separation strip
Between April 1943 and January 1945 the Separation Strip separated the POW camp from the concentration camp. Fencing was double and straw mats were placed to prevent view from one side to the other. Guarding of the prisoners was separated between the Wehrmacht for POWs and SS for the conncetration camp prisoners.The nine meter high towers were manned with guards around the clock. At night, the camp would be lit by spotlights. The guard posts were fitted with telephones and binoculars and the guards were armed with machine guns.

This meant that several places on work details became vacant and the Greeks, being the longest-serving inmates in the camp, were able to make suggestions to the Germans as to who would be suitable for them. text:
27 August 1944
On the other hand, if it continues to rain, what will I do with my legs? You not get my drift, do you? That is because you do not know the meaning of space. You have a few cubic metres to yourself. You call it ‘room’. In that room you have placed some objects, called chairs and tables, and when you want to eat, you sit yourself at a table on a chair, and in such a way that every person in the room has a chair, and in front of him on the table enough space for his plate and a piece of bread. There are even chairs to spare in the room. When it rains, though … where and how must I eat then? When the sun shines, we sit outdoors. Outdoors there are tables, benches and stools. True, there is not enough room for everyone at once, but one can wait, or rather, can let another wait. When it rains, though, we are unable to sit outdoors. Indoors it is like a Jewish warehouse; the coffins in which we sleep are piled three high, with only twenty centimetres between them. So where must we eat then? We eat together, my wife and I. We sit on her bunk. Below us is a Greek tailor with his wife and child. Fortunately, there is no one above us yet. In my wife’s hut the beds are still only two-tiered. Hence the Greek tailor together with his wife and child are able to sit below us, because there is adequate space between the first and the second bunks. If the beds are three-tiered, the legs of the beds have been shortened. The distance between the first two tiers is then most fifty centimetres, so that one can sit only on the top bunk. If you are lucky, there may even be a further ten centimetres or so of space between your head and the rafters. But in either case the problem is always one’s legs. In our case, the Greek tailor and his wife are not at all pleased that we clamber on top to eat and sit there. The roads are muddy and dirty, and my shoes are like the road! And it is not pleasant to see the shoes of a fellow citizen dangling above your meagre soup, not once, but day after day, week after week, month after month, as they did last winter. The worthy pastor will say people ought to love one another. But the worthy pastor has void which he calls a room, his room, and he has a chair, his chair, and a table, his table. I should like to know what his love for mankind would be like if every morning, every afternoon and every evening my legs were to dangle above his slice of bread, his soup, his gravy, meat, vegetables, potatoes – an dessert. We long for some space. My Greek tailor does protest occasionally, but I think to myself: my dear man, you are an angel. And I am able to think it all the more, because I cannot understand the curses he undoubtedly casts my way. […]

30 August 1944
“BB, 30 August ’44. […] This regular roll-call goes on for at least two to three hours every day. And very often, almost every two days, it is extended on some pretext or because of some ‘accident’ to last five to six hours or even the whole day in any kind of weather. But apart from these regular roll-calls, we also often have to line up because of some absurd order, no matter what the time of day, and listen to some announcement. Then two or three officers arrive, review the roll-call, and woe betide those who dare to move and thus disturb the ‘order’. It’s a harrowing image, especially when you see old men or women, for example from the southern parts of our country, shivering from cold and fear before one of these criminals, a Prussian sapling. They embody a whole human life, lived modestly and honestly, in most cases also many years of hard, diligent labour and the traditional respect for other human beings, and now they’re completely reduced to standing to attention in front of some villain who spits his mad rage in their faces and tramples on their souls and human dignity. text:
February 1945
"BB. February 1945. I share my bed with Mrs. G., a fairly corpulent woman in her fifties who has been literally immobilized by disease, hunger, and nicotine. Confined to her bed, heavy and inert like lead, she never gets up. All day long, I don't know what to do with my body; I can't get the slightest space in this damned bed to rest my slowly atrophying limbs a little. Breathing has become nearly impossible for me, too. 
In the evening, I sink into our shared, damp hole on the lowest level of a bed whose upper two levels are occupied by three adults and two children. Our bed is right next to the wall, or rather, those worm-eaten planks that rain seeps through ceaselessly. The window and the door are also nearby. The dampness has penetrated everywhere, soaking everything, clothing, bodies, blankets... Things aren't damp here, they're drenched. Water and mud everywhere, inside and out. And along with them, the air saturated by the suffocating odor exhaled by those suffering from typhus and the stench of urine. Is this a bed? Call it what you want, but not a bed. A muddy swamp.
Climbing out of this hole in the morning, my face is completely swollen, my eyelids are sealed, and it takes an hour or two for me to be able to open my eyes and see clearly around me. Each time I wonder if I've gone blind. This is certainly not a bed, it's a tomb - a tomb built for two."

text:
22 April 1944
“Saturday, 22 April 1944. […] The so-called shoe factory is located inside a brick-built stable. Around 120 women work in a single room. We sit on these terribly hard stools at wooden tables amid piles of old shoes. The muggy, dusty air makes breathing difficult, and very soon your back begins to hurt from permanently sitting in a crouched position. Our daily quota is to rip up 40 pairs of old shoes, unstitch them seam for seam with unsuitable tools. The parts are then sorted and thrown into Wehrmacht helmets that have been provided for the purpose. Our diligent labour is supposed to win Germany the victory! One helmet is marked for reusable leather, another for scraps, and yet another for pieces of fabric. The “good” pieces are those that the Germans want to make composition leather from. Our favourite helmet is the one intended for the leather scraps. It always fills up fastest, because cutting up good leather into small scraps is the only opportunity for sabotage open to us. The fabric, which sounds much too good a term for those dusty, dirty rags, is desperately needed in the latrines, but more on that later. In total, there may be around 600 men and women crouching over those shoes. Sure, the work may not really be all that hard, but crouching on a rickety wooden stool for eleven hours, hungry and freezing, that’s enough to do us in. And then there’s that awful dust. Your throat gets dry, your eyes get sore and your back hurts between the shoulder blades. I’m sore from sitting down for so long, my stomach hurts, but what hurts the most is the pain I feel from doing this inhumane, useless and empty work. And then there’s the eternal talk about food. People constantly think up new meals that never get served, or dream up ever more imaginative dishes they never taste. They don’t talk about anything else but food! The only relief from this monotonous daily routine is when you get to secretly smoke a cigarette during latrine break. The latrine is a simple wooden cabin with an iron bar over a cesspit, and this is also where all the political rumours originate that are flying around the camp.”

The punishment for stealing bread
“Because I was German, I was unfortunately left in charge of a group of foreign comrades on timber detail. The camp’s timber yard was immediately adjacent to the crematorium and was surrounded by a fence. In this enclosure stood another wooden hut. I later discovered that several loaves of bread had been stacked up there. I used my hatchet to break off two boards and took four wholemeal loaves, which I distributed among my comrades. They were so hungry that they gobbled it down, which wasn’t all that easy because the bread was so dry. [...] Then I had to report with the work detail to the Blockführer. [...] The Blockführer immediately asked me if I had stolen bread. My answering in the negative did not help me, because the guards had searched the prisoners and had discovered that most of them had hidden bits of bread on their person. [...] The punishment [of 25 blows] was administered with the leg of a stool under the supervision of the SS Blockführer and the camp elder. I experienced the first three blows before I blacked out. Food rations
“The food has grown significantly worse since the move. At midday we now receive a soup made of cabbage or spinach, but which has almost no fat. For our bread there is margarine instead of butter, and instead of the good jam there is an acidic compote. We haven't received our evening soup for a whole month. We all feel bad, we are all constantly hungry and irritated. We’ve never quarrelled so much before. Acquaintances fight, impatient mothers hit their children, married couples have on-going wars of words. If we receive a few days’ worth of bread rations, we use a knife to mark how much of the bread we can eat each day. Anyone who can’t control themselves eats their entire ration in the first days and has to go without bread in the last days. Then you just lie in bed. It’s easier to bear the hunger lying down."

text:
Moving in February 1945
"We’re supposed to move again, and this time we’re happy about the change. The huts are damp. There are many holes in the roof, and when it rains, the rain drips on the heads and bedding of the inhabitants of the top bunks. Anyone who has a canopy hangs it above their bunk. But anyone who doesn’t have one, like most of us, is exposed to the wetness. Blankets and pillows are permanently damp, even the bread, which is kept in a box at the end of the bed. Rheumatism troubles us greatly. But this move is delayed day after day, for weeks. Finally [...] we move into our huts, which are far from ours at the edge of the forest. Our neighbours are the Hungarians who came here five weeks ago from a labour camp. They look terrible. Gaunt, starving, ragged figures. They stand at the wire mesh fence and delouse themselves all day long. Their clothing, their blankets, their bodies are ridden with lice. We’ve never seen anything like it. The hut is narrow. 450 people live, sleep and eat in a long room. We have three-tier bunks. Two people have to sleep on each tier. It gets more and more crowded. Mothers sleep with their children, married couples sleep together. I sleep with Micki, my husband sleeps with a colleague. No one can sleep well. But we’re all getting weaker and hungrier. Many of us have swollen legs, swollen faces. Many are still suffering from as yet unhealed abdominal typhus. I’m already so weak that I can no longer walk. Even speaking is an effort for me. I can only whisper. I can barely look after Micki anymore. I have no strength."

From a personal account written in June 1945 in St. Maur, France

Selection for an exchange
“Thursday, 26 April. Yesterday a transport made up of six Palestine lists comprising older men and women came to Hut 10 (where we were in quarantine). It’s said that they are going to be exchanged to Palestine, something which provokes much discussion. The chance of exchange has passed for me, because it turns out that they will not take anyone fit for military service; the most I can hope for is internment. It was a barbaric process. The day before, Palestine people had to step forward during the work roll-call, a few bigwigs came along, someone read out the names of around 250 people who lined up. After that had gone on for about two hours, in the pouring rain, we who had not been called were allowed to go back home, and we earned ourselves an afternoon off, while those who had been called were given instructions. The next day, again at the work roll-call, which the non-workers were now also ordered to attend, another 250 people were called, but then some others as well who were given fifteen minutes time, all of them elderly or women and children. After that we marched to work without a farewell, not even from Uncle Abel; but there are also men whose wives are going away. The ‘ten’ are now strictly isolated from the rest of the camp, barbed wire and guards. The work will not do me in, but in the long run the hunger and lack of sun probably will."

"A year ago Mams and I looked at each other: We’re trapped. The repugnant smell of turnips filled the air. (I would give a lot for a bowl of soup from back then, which still contained fat and a bit of meat and potatoes. We haven’t seen any fruit, any eggs or any butter for a year. They’ve crossed the Rhine; the bombing is continuous, just like last year.) [...] I can barely work anymore, my legs are giving in, and I see no chance of escaping the grip of this hospital. text:
Daily Life
[missing translation] Der Alltag im Konzentrationslager Bergen-Belsen war zwischen den Bereichen des Austauschlagers und dem Männer- und Frauenlager sehr unterschiedlich. Im Verlauf der Lagerzeit verschlechterten sich die Bedingungen darüber hinaus für alle Häftlinge gleichermaßen. Für die Häftlinge im Austauschlager richtete die SS zunächst eine Selbstverwaltung ein, die unter anderem für die Ordnung im Lager, die Einteilung zu den Arbeitskommandos, die Zuteilung auf die Baracken und den Kontakt zur SS verantwortlich war. Während im Sternlager eine Arbeitspflicht für alle erwachsenen Häftlinge galt, waren die Häftlinge im Neutralen-, Sonder- und Ungarnlager davon ausgenommen. Für Kinder wurde zeitweilig in kleinen Gruppen heimlicher Unterricht organisiert und mit vereinzelten kulturellen Darbietungen versuchten die Häftlinge des Austauschlagers, sich abzulenken und als Menschen selbst zu behaupten. Im Frauen- und Männerlager bestand von Beginn an das System der Funktionshäftlinge. Die SS übertrug einzelnen Häftlingen Funktionen und Aufgaben. Sie wurden zu sogenannten Kapos, Lagerältesten, Block- und Stubenältesten bestimmt; Häftlinge wurden als Pfleger und Ärzte eingesetzt. Sie hatten in ihren jeweiligen Positionen Macht über andere Häftlinge und Möglichkeiten, Mithäftlingen zu helfen. Die räumliche Enge durch die große Überfüllung der Baracken und die völlig unzureichende Ernährung prägte den Alltag aller Häftlinge. Die täglichen Appelle, die die SS oft stundenlang abhalten ließ, bedeuteten für die entkräfteten Häftlinge eine ständige und häufig tödliche Qual. Darüber hinaus lebten sie in dem dauernden Bewusstsein der willkürlichen Schikanen durch SS oder Funktionshäftlinge.

text:
Liberation and its aftermath
With the front approaching, the Wehrmacht and the SS surrendered Bergen-Belsen concentration camp peacefully to the British army in the context of a local truce and before most of the prisoners had been evacuated. The British troops were in no way prepared for the inferno they were confronted with when they arrived at Bergen-Belsen on the afternoon of 15 April 1945. They immediately implemented relief measures which were continued and intensified over the following days and weeks. Despite all efforts to save the prisoners, the dying in Bergen-Belsen continued. By mid-May, another 12,500 liberated prisoners had died of the effects of their incarceration. Already in 1945 memorials stones and monuments were put up by survivors on the site of the former POW and concentration camp. In 1952 the Memorial was inaugurated after an obelisk and a wall of inscriptions were built. Until today, changes of the Memorial also reflect a changing political and societal situation.

text:
Roll call
Each of the strictly separated camp sections at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp had its own roll-call square. The SS held roll calls every day and in any kind of weather to count the thousands of prisoners. During these roll calls, prisoners had to stand to attention, usually in rows of five. Additional roll calls were also held, sometimes several times a day. The many roll calls represented a permanent physical and psychological strain for the prisoners. Particularly sick or old prisoners and children found it very hard to stand to attention for prolonged periods.

text:
Arrival at the Women's camp
"We had to line up again in rows of five. Stiff from sitting, dirty and crumpled, we stood at the train station of Bergen-Belsen. [...] After a two-hour march by foot, during which we even occassionally sang a Dutch song, we reached the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. The camp was in the middle of the woods. But was it really a camp? We could only see large tents. From these shelters a screaming and noise arose, you did not know what hit you. Were there girls living in there? Was it worse here than in Auschwitz? Our eyes searched for the chimneys, the ovens, but no, smoke was nowhere to be seen, nor were there gas chambers. Would we reach freedom at last? As we were walking through the gate, we were counted by four to five SS men. We passed by one after another and as the last one had gone through, the gate closed behind us, and we were locked up again, our freedom had been taken. As we were walking one after another each of us became two amazing woolen army blankets and a small pot with a spoon. Such luxury! Woolen blankets, a clean spoon and a clean pot. We were brought to a large field, where small heath bushes were growing here and there. We were standing there for hours, without food, without drinks, tired, cold and sad. The screams in the tents in front of us continued, and after a while the volume seemed twice as high. We did not understand. In the distance, pots with food were carried around. Was there a great hunger here as well? For the first time we saw the girls, that lived in Bergen-Belsen. Upon our arrival it had been strictly forbidden to get in touch with us. Everything had been shielded by the SS. Now, during the food distribution, we saw the girls. Oh, how shocked we were. In striped clothes and jackets these poor creatures were walking around, without socks, without stockings, without shoes, no headscarves, nothing. Their faces were emaciated, hollow from hunger. What hell could we expect once again? The Germans had lied to us again. There were no factories here. There were no decent huts. There was no sanitary. No, just misery, dirt and hunger. Our illusions dissolved."

Meeting Anne Frank again
"We were in Bergen-Belsen. Everyone would become tin bowl, a spoon and a blanket again. Jannie and I were lucky, at the end of the queue many people did not get anything anymore. We were freezing, we put our blankets around ourselves and were tired as hell. But we were relieved. There were no gas chambers here, nor was there a crematorium... Finally, we got something to eat, a soup with a few pieces of turnip. Turnip was something special. Then we could walk around freely. Someone told us, that we could wash ourselves somewhere on a small hill. We walked and there was a long water pipe with many taps. To wash ourselves with fresh, cold water, had not been possibly since Auschwitz. We covered ourselves in our blankets again, and then two skinny, close shorn figures walked towards us, they looked like small freezing birds. We hugged each other and cried. They were Margot and Anne Frank. We asked them about their mother. Anne just said: "selected". The four of us went back to the roll-call square, we passed by barracks. Then we reached multiple large tents, it looked like a circus had settled here. We were put into these tents. We were laying on straw and huddled together under our blankets. During the first days it was quiet, we slept a lot. It started to rain. Even our blankets could not keep us warm. There were lice here again too. Then we were called to work. In a hut, we had to tear the soles from old shoes, a laborious task. But we got some soup and bread. Soon our hands started to bleed and discharge pus. Anne and I had to quit the work first, it was simply not possible anymore. Jannie and Margot persisted a little longer."

text:
Different sections: the Exchange Camp
Only a few Jews were explicitly excluded from the racist persecution by Nazi Germany. These were people whom the SS and the German Foreign Office thought might be useful to them in some way. The German Foreign Office and the SS were planning to exchange the Jews imprisoned in Bergen-Belsen for Germans interned by enemy nations or for urgently needed goods and foreign currency or because they were nationals of neutral or friendly states.  Starting in July 1943, the SS brought the first exchange prisoners from Greece, from the Westerbork transit camp in the Netherlands and from the ghettos in Poland to Bergen-Belsen. The exchange camp was divided into different sections for the various groups  of prisoners that were separated by barbed wire fences. Prisoners could  wear their civilian clothes in all camp sections; men and women were housed separately, and children up to the age of 14 stayed with their mothers.

Different sections: the Men's and Women's Camps
In Bergen-Belsen, too, the SS set up a separate camp section in which sick male prisoners from other concentration camps were housed from March 1944. From mid-August 1944, the SS brought female concentration camp prisoners to Bergen-Belsen. They were initially housed in tents in a provisional camp section and later in huts. Several thousand of these female prisoners were taken from there to the satellite camps at armaments factories to perform slave labour. Many stayed behind, and some of them were also forced to perform slave labour at Bergen-Belsen. Little historical evidence survives to document the suffering and death of these men and women.

text:
Labour in the camp
While adult prisoners in the star camp were obliged to go to work, prisoners in the other parts of the exchange camp were excluded from this. The “shoe detail” was the largest work detail at the star camp. Its members had to take apart old shoes and cut out reusable pieces of scrap leather. Other work details were regularly working in the kitchens, were doing forestry or worked in construction inside the camp. The prisoners in the men's and the women's camps could sign up for a work detail and got a little extra food as their wage. This chance for better care however meant hard physical labour and the risk of chicanery.

text:
Children
At least 2,750 children and teenagers were imprisoned in the Bergen-Belsen exchange camp. Most of them arrived there with their parents. Up until the age of 14, children were housed with their mothers. The older ones were put into the men’s or women’s huts respectively. Teenagers in the Star Camp who were over the age of 14 were forced to work on work details. From the moment they arrived at the camp, the children were subjected to the same inhumane camp rules as the adults. They had to stand at roll-call for hours, their lives were confined by barbed wire, and they suffered from hunger and fear. The children were left to their own devices during the day when the adults were forced to work. As hunger, disease and death came to dominate everyday life at the camp during the last months before liberation, the children were increasingly left to their fate.

Transport of the children
"We were herded into the building, which turned out to be the SS garage. When we entered, we saw the luggage our mothers had taken with them and understodd that they must have been ordered to leave it behind in the garage. [...] I was sitting on one of our suitcases when two shadowy figures appeared in the doorway. A torch was lit and shone into the garage. One of the two walked in and switched on the lights. What a sorry sight we must have been. About forty children were huddled together in the corner with tired, tear-stained faces. As I was the nearest one, the guards asked me where we came from. I told him that we had come from Sternlager at about four o'clock that afternoon. [...] I walked back to where the small children were sitting huddled together on the floor. Their eyes swollen from crying, they were totally exhausted by their ordeal. The worst of the wailing had quietened down. They were spent. Some of the little ones were even asleep on the cold concrete floor. [...] Everybody was so very tired from the long, long hours on our feet, the traumatic upheaval we had experienced, as well as having had nothing to eat all day. It became quiet now. Most of the little one were sleeping. By now the older ones were talking to each other in low tones, all afraid to go to sleep. I was tired but not sleepy. About an hour after the guard had left us, he returned with two male prisoners who each carried a large carton. At the same time, a car arrived. Two men entered the garage with their arms full of blankets. I recognized the men from our camp. When Mr Weiss had found out that we were being held in the SS garage, they arranged for the blankets to be delivered to us. How they had been able to arrange this was a mystery to me, but we were very glad as now the older children could have some covers as well.[...] It was now half-past eleven. The chilly outside air penetrated the garage. Trucks could be heard coming down the road. They stopped in front of the garage, Then two SS officers and a female guard entered. Most of the children who had been asleep woke up; a few kept sleeping from sheer exhaustion. We were told to move unto the trucks."

text:
Prisoners from the Netherlands
In May 1940, the German Wehrmacht invaded the Netherlands. The Nazi regime created the “Reichskommissariat Niederlande”, an administrative province of the German Reich, and tried to implement their policies through local institutions. The majority of Dutch people disliked the German occupation, and the German occupiers reacted with increasing brutality to the widespread disobedience and resistance. Soon, arbitrary raids, arrests and shootings became the order of the day. 120,000 Dutch people were deported to Germany for forced labour and thousands were imprisoned in the camps at Amersfoort and Vught, from where they were deported to German concentration camps.
In the Netherlands, Jews were more firmly integrated into mainstream society than in most other European countries. In 1941, around 140,000 Jews lived there, including 22,000 refugees, most of them from Germany. The new regulations brought in by the Germans pushed the Jews more and more to the margins of society, and in July 1942, the deportations started. More than 100,000 Jews were transported to the east via the Westerbork “Police Transit Camp for Jews”. Most were taken directly to the Auschwitz or Sobibór extermination camps, but around 4,000 Jews were transported to the Bergen-Belsen exchange camp. Fewer than 5,000 of those who were deported from Westerbork survived their time in the camps.
Prisoners from the Netherlands were held in all camp sections of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.
Between September 1943 and September 1944, around 4,000 Jews were taken from Westerbork to the Bergen-Belsen exchange camp (Star Camp). Among these prisoners were many children and teenagers. The SS intended to use them as hostages for possible exchanges, but only around 400 of them were ever actually released. At least 948 of them died in Bergen-Belsen, and 1,000 Dutch prisoners were transported on to other camps.
In early April 1945, the exchange camp was evacuated and the prisoners, including 1,500 people who had been deported from Westerbork, were put on three large transports which left Bergen-Belsen for Theresienstadt. Most of them were liberated after a two-week odyssey near Tröbitz in the Niederlausitz region in eastern Germany, while a smaller group was liberated at Farsleben near Magdeburg. Shortly before their liberation and in the weeks after, 200 people died of the consequences of their imprisonment and the additional strain of the evacuation transports.
Henrik Abspoel, a political prisoner from The Hague, was given the prisoner number 1 at the Bergen-Belsen men’s camp. He died at the age of 42 only nine days after his arrival in Bergen-Belsen. Over 300 other Dutch prisoners in the men’s camp are known by name.
More than 100 women from the Netherlands were taken to the Bergen-Belsen women’s camp from November 1944, including many Jewish women who had initially been deported to Auschwitz from Westerbork.
In total, well over 5,000 men, women and children from the Netherlands were imprisoned in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.

text:
Diaries from Bergen-Belsen
The diaries that prisoners secretly kept in Bergen-Belsen are very important documents. Their authors took these notes in order to bear witness to the crimes committed, and in order to distance themselves from the unbearable reality of everyday life at the camp.
The conditions at the camp made keeping a diary very difficult. The prisoners had to organise paper and pens, and they needed to find a safe hiding place for their diary. Also, they had to find time to write in their diaries during their short periods of rest and thus lost precious sleep. Discovery of the notes by the SS meant grave danger for the diary’s author.
Because the SS burned the camp’s files shortly before the arrival of the British Army, the diaries, alongside some lists of names and records kept by prisoners, today form the main body of surviving written historical documents from Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. 27 diaries written in the exchange camp survived. Other diaries were destroyed by their owners because they were afraid the SS might find them.

On Shabbath and during the week somebody read from the Thora. It was a beautiful Sefer Thora with a crimson coat that was kept in a special board of the locker – all property of the Antwerp Jeshiva’s teacher Burak.

Thus, a Portuguese from Saloniki prayed in the typically monotonous way of the Sephards and a Turk from Milano sang the priestly blessing, wrapped in the Tallid. Then again, you would hear an Argentine from Antwerp pray with the ailing voice of a pious Jew while another Argentine from Krakow would sing with the strong passion of the Chassidic way first doleful and later joyful songs. A man from Hamburg pointed to the meaning of this time of suffering and hope for the Jewish people in the dignified form of a French speech. text:
Exchange
After the outbreak of the war, some Jewish nationals of either neutral or pro-German states still remained in the German sphere of control. These Jews were imprisoned in camps but were initially spared deportation to the extermination camps. In the autumn of 1942, the German Foreign Office, in an attempt to avoid possible conflict, began to contact the respective governments and asked them to “repatriate” their subjects. The states in question, which included Spain and Turkey, then began to consider whether or not to recognise the nationalities of the prisoners. 
Exchanges of internees between the German Reich and Britain had already occurred in 1941 and 1942. On these occasions, Jews with papers for Palestine imprisoned in Germany had been released in exchange for German nationals interned in Palestine. The SS and the German Foreign Office intended to use the Bergen-Belsen prisoners to expand this exchange. 
After the mass deportations of Hungarian Jews to the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp had begun, Rezsö (Rudolf) Kasztner conducted negotiations with the SS on behalf of the Budapest-based Aid and Rescue Committee regarding the rescue of Jews.

text:
Transports from the Exchange Camp
Between July and September 1943, the SS deported around 2,500 Jews from Warsaw and other Polish cities to the exchange camp Bergen-Belsen. Most of them had passports from Latin American countries. However, when approached by the German Foreign Office, the Latin American governments refused to recognise the majority of these papers. In the eyes of the Foreign Office and the SS the prisoners had thus lost their value. In October 1943, the SS selected around 1,800 prisoners and told them they would be transferred to a camp called Bergau for an eventual exchange. Instead, the group was taken on a transport to the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp, where all of its members were murdered upon arrival.
In February and May 1944, another 350 prisoners from the Bergen-Belsen Special Camp were taken to Auschwitz.

In early April 1945, the SS evacuated the vast majority of prisoners from the exchange camp. Between 6 and 10 April 1945, around 6,700 prisoners were to be taken on three trains, probably to the Theresienstadt ghetto. However, only one of these transports actually arrived in Theresienstadt, where the prisoners were liberated on 8 May by Soviet troops. The other two trains were liberated on 13 April near Farsleben by American troops and on 23 April near Tröbitz by Soviet troops.
These transports were an additional strain on the already weakened prisoners. In the train liberated near Tröbitz alone, at least 133 prisoners died during the journey. In total, several hundred prisoners of the exchange camp lost their lives during the evacuation transports and the first weeks after liberation.

text:
The Prisoners' options
In the exchange camp, like in all other concentration camps, the SS assigned individual prisoners to act as Lagerälteste (camp elders) and Blockälteste (block elders). These prisoner functionaries had to carry out the orders given by the SS and had very little leeway in doing so. They were only able to exert some influence on the distribution of food or the assignment of prisoners to individual work details.
Deprived of all rights as they were and faced with arbitrary violent treatment at the hands of the SS, the prisoners found it difficult to maintain moral values in everyday life. This became all the more problematic as their food situation deteriorated and the struggle for survival intensified.
Despite these conditions, the prisoners tried to keep up at least some semblance of a civilised life. Such efforts included the establishment of special camp courts, run by the prisoners themselves, which mostly dealt with cases of bread theft.

text:
Josef Weiss
Josef Weiss was born on 16 May 1893 in Flamersheim near Bonn. 
His family fled from the Nazis to the Netherlands, and he followed them in the summer of 1933. In the Netherlands, he managed a leather goods factory and worked for the Dutch Zionist Association, the Nederlandse Zionisten Bond (NZB). In late January 1942, Josef Weiss, his wife and their younger son were imprisoned in the Westerbork camp. In January 1944, the family was transported to the Bergen-Belsen exchange camp. There, Josef Weiss was initially the deputy to the representative of the Jewish prisoners at the Star Camp, the Judenältester, and from December 1944 he held that position himself. In this capacity, he was able to alleviate conditions for many prisoners. Survivors have described him as a “towering figure” at the camp.
The Weiss family was liberated on 23 April 1945 in Tröbitz. Erna Weiss-Falk died there of the effects of her imprisonment on 6 May. In the summer of 1945, Josef Weiss returned to the Netherlands. Two years later, he emigrated to Palestine.
Josef Weiss died on 12 September 1976 in Jerusalem.

One night I slept in this barrack, with the male night nurse who was ill. He had been lying all day on his and my blanket and had something coming on. Religious life
Religious life also took place in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Due to its specific circumstances, religious activities in the exchange camp are better known than those from the men’s and the women’s camps. Most of the prisoners of the exchange camp were Jewish and because of their special status they had some items with them like Talid, Tefillin or Tora, and Talmud. In all parts of the exchange camp, some men tried to gather in minyan and pray at least for Shabbath. High feasts like Jom Kippur or Pesach were observed and celebrated. Pesach, for example, was widely remembered also because of its resemblance to the prisoners’ own situation of persecution.
In the men’s and the women’s camps, mainly individual praying, both Jewish and Christian, took place.

text:
Housing
After arriving at the train stop outside Bergen the prisoners were marched some five miles to the camp. There they were housed in wooden or stone huts, but also in large tents for a while. Families were separated by gender; children up to the age of 14 usually stayed with their mothers.
Inside the huts the prisoners suffered from the cold, parasites, inadequate sanitation and overcrowding. More and more people were forced to share pallets in bunk beds that often had more than two tiers. In some areas of the camp people had to lie on the bare floor and were given no blankets. Adequate clothing and shoes of the right size were another problem. People who had previously been imprisoned in ghettos and other camps usually only had rags left to wear.

text:
Death in the camp
The prisoners experienced every form of violence at the concentration camp, as witnesses and victims. The brutal and indiscriminate treatment the SS meted out to them posed a constant threat to them.
But hunger was the worst enemy: it became the defining element in the lives of all the prisoners and knew no age limit. The prisoners were given less and less to eat. The existential crisis worsened, and more than ever before the children were reliant on the support of older prisoners or their own initiative to obtain food.
As prisoner numbers increased and food rations deteriorated, more and more diseases and epidemics swept through the camp from autumn 1944 onwards. Prisoners lost their family members and friends – and death became a part of their everyday lives. Typhus and typhoid fever claimed many victims. The prisoners were too weak and malnourished to fight these diseases. The mortality rate soared, among adults as among children.

It was strange to see how easy it was to say goodbye to people with whom one had lived and worked day in and day out. The 'unknown children'
The group of so-called ‘unknown children’ were transported to Bergen-Belsen from Westerbork in September 1944. These children had been discovered without relatives by German authorities in hiding places in the Netherlands. In many cases, their identity could not be traced clearly. As they did not want to risk deporting and killing ‘Aryan’ children the SS took the group of these children to Bergen-Belsen first while continuing to research their identities. Later on in November, they were transported to Theresienstadt, another camp where the SS gathered prisoners exempt from immediate extermination for negotiation purposes.

The moment of liberation
When British soldiers entered the camp on 15 April 1945 they found themselves in surroundings beyond imagination, that later on many referred to as the hell of Belsen. About 38,000 prisoners were barely alive, starving and sick. Apathy ruled in the camp. While those strong enough expressed joy and relief over the arrival of the British, to other prisoners the moment of liberation seemed less important than their immediate ongoing struggle for life and the caring for family members just dying. Even though the liberation secured most prisoners’ physical survival their lives lay shattered and it took time and effort to build new families, homes, a future.

text:
Transports to and from the exchange camp
Between 7 July 1943 and 14 December 1944, around 62 transports arrived to the Bergen-Belsen exchange camp. Some people believed in the option for release from persecution, some knew vaguely about Bergen-Belsen as a kind of privileged camp, others did not know why they ended up here. In general, none of them could be certain about the fate that awaited them. In fact, a few transports did leave the camp taking prisoners to Palestine, Spain, Switzerland or Turkey as release measures. Still, the majority stayed in Bergen-Belsen and was liberated on one of the three evacuation transports in April 1945. However, when forged papers of prisoners were not recognised by the claimed countries’ embassies, some groups of prisoners from the exchange camp were deported to Auschwitz and other camps where the prisoners were killed or had to perform slave labour.

text:
Transports to and from the men's and women's camps
Except for the around 520 concentration camp prisoners who carried out preparation work for the planned imprisonment of around 10,000 exchange prisoners in spring 1943, no transport arrived to the men’s camp until March 1944. From then on, mainly prisoners too sick to perform slave labour in other camps were deported here. Many of them did not live to be liberated. From August 1944 on, transports with female prisoners were sent to the women’s camp of Bergen-Belsen.
Transports of prisoners continued to arrive at Bergen-Belsen concentration camp until just before the camp’s liberation by British troops.
The SS still transported male prisoners from other concentration camps who were critically ill and judged unfit for work to the men’s camp. Female prisoners were taken to the women’s camp, from where many of them were sent to satellite camps of other concentration camps to perform slave labour. However, the number of sick and weakened women who remained in Bergen-Belsen continued to grow.
The SS took the prisoners from evacuated concentration camps to Bergen-Belsen by train or on foot. These journeys in overcrowded cattle cars and the death marches sometimes lasted for weeks. Countless people died of malnutrition, disease and exhaustion, and many were shot or beaten to death by the guards.

27 August 1944, II
"So where must we eat then? We eat together, my wife and I. We sit on her bunk. Below us is a Greek tailor with his wife and child. Fortunately, there is no one above us yet. In my wife’s hut the beds are still only two-tiered. Hence the Greek tailor together with his wife and child are able to sit below us, because there is adequate space between the first and the second bunks. If the beds are three-tiered, the legs of the beds have been shortened. The distance between the first two tiers is then most fifty centimetres, so that one can sit only on the top bunk. If you are lucky, there may even be a further ten centimetres or so of space between your head and the rafters. But in either case the problem is always one’s legs. In our case, the Greek tailor and his wife are not at all pleased that we clamber on top to eat and sit there. The roads are muddy and dirty, and my shoes are like the road! And it is not pleasant to see the shoes of a fellow citizen dangling above your meagre soup, not once, but day after day, week after week, month after month, as they did last winter. The worthy pastor will say people ought to love one another. But the worthy pastor has void which he calls a room, his room, and he has a chair, his chair, and a table, his table. I should like to know what his love for mankind would be like if every morning, every afternoon and every evening my legs were to dangle above his slice of bread, his soup, his gravy, meat, vegetables, potatoes – an dessert. We long for some space. My Greek tailor does protest occasionally, but I think to myself: my dear man, you are an angel. And I am able to think it all the more, because I cannot understand the curses he undoubtedly casts my way. […]"

When the British troops arrived at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, they were not prepared for what they found: epidemics such as typhoid fever and typhus were raging through the camp, and the prisoners were suffering from extreme malnutrition. The liberators set up an emergency hospital in buildings at the nearby Wehrmacht barracks where they treated the many thousands of critically ill survivors. Civilian aid organisations supported the military units in looking after the survivors. Despite immediate relief efforts, more than 14,000 former prisoners died during the first three months after liberation.
When the number of patients finally decreased the barrack buildings that had been used for the emergency hospital were transformed into provisional housing for the liberated prisoners. Patients who still needed to be treated in hospital were taken to the former German military hospital located outside the barracks.
The medical officer in charge of organising and implementing all medical aid was Brigadier General H.L. Glyn Hughes.

The headquarters of Stalag XI C (311) Bergen-Belsen
The camp's headquarters were staffed with reserve officers, many of whom were over 60 years old and had already served in World War I.
The POWs were guarded by soldiers who could not be deployed to the front because of their age or physical afflictions. These soldiers made up the territorial units (Landesschützen).
The guidelines for the conduct towards Soviet POWs issued by the Wehrmacht High Command demanded a ruthless treatment of these prisoners without any respect for martial or international law. Many soldiers acted accordingly, others sometimes used the leeway they had to the prisoners’ advantage.

text:
Prisoners of war
In 1941, the Wehrmacht set up camps to house Soviet POWs. The military, the authorities and the general population referred to these camps as “Russians’ camps”.
The German Reich was divided into military districts (Wehrkreise) which were identified by Roman numerals. The Hanover military district, for example, had the number XI. The POW camps were identified by the number of the military district and a capital letter. The camps exclusively for Soviet POWs were marked with an additional number in brackets, e.g. XI C (311) Bergen-Belsen.
After their arrival, the prisoners had to undergo registration procedures. Their clothes and personal possessions were checked, they underwent a medical examination, and they were vaccinated and registered. Each prisoner was given an ID tag which he had to wear around his neck at all times, and his personal details were entered on a “personal index card I”. Information such as time spent on work details, transfers to other camps, treatment in the hospital or punishments received was also entered on these cards.

The Bergen-Belsen Polish DP Camp, 1945-1946
For some periods between April 1945 and August 1946, considerably more than 10,000 of the 230,000 Polish displaced persons in the British zone lived in the Bergen-Belsen DP camp. These DPs included survivors of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, as well as former prisoners of other concentration camps and liberated Polish prisoners of war and slave labourers.
Immediately after the liberation of Bergen-Belsen, Polish survivors founded a committee. Its members organised everyday life in the DP camp and acted as representatives of the DPs in dealing with the British authorities. The first meetings of the committee were also attended by Polish Jews.

The soldiers’ meals were prepared in the service huts (“Wirtschaftsbarracken” or W.B.) and served in the canteens there, where alcohol was sometimes offered as well.

text:
Professional Training in the DP-Camp
For the adults at the camp, Nazi persecution had also meant that they had been torn away from their working lives, often for years. Most teenagers and young adults did not have any professional training, a deficit they made up for at the DP camp. This training was of great importance to the DPs because they wanted to build new lives for themselves after their emigration. Learning crafts and sometimes also agricultural professions was especially important for those who wanted to emigrate to Palestine (and later to the newly founded State of Israel).
Courses in which the DPs were taught professional skills were organised especially by the Jewish relief organisation ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation and Training). The organisation’s training workshops carried out repairs and produced items needed at the camp. By mid-1947, over 1,500 persons had attended ORT courses, which usually lasted around six months.

Tens of thousands of concentration camp prisoners arrived at the loading platform outside Bergen.
The loading platform was built as part of the rail link for the nearby military training area in 1936. The prisoners who arrived there between 1943 and 1945, most of them weakened and sick, had to march the four miles to the Bergen-Belsen main camp.

Prisoners who were too weak to march to the camp were shot by

text:
The Barracks Camp
The Bergen-Hohne military training area with its extensive barracks complex was established from 1935 as part of the Nazi regime’s preparations for war.
In early April 1945, the Wehrmacht vacated the south-eastern section of the barracks. Between 8 and 11 April 1945, more than 15,000 male prisoners from the Mittelbau-Dora camp complex were housed there. More than half of these prisoners were from the Soviet Union and Poland and had been persecuted on political grounds.
Conditions at the barracks camp were slightly better than at the main camp a little over a mile to the south. Nevertheless, hundreds of prisoners died at the barracks camp within a short period of time. Most of them died from hunger and disease, others were shot by the guards made up of SS men and Hungarian soldiers. After the liberation, dozens of prisoner functionaries (kapos) were lynched by other prisoners.

text:
The Bergen-Belsen Jewish DP Camp, 1945-1950
In the autumn of 1945, after repatriation had been completed for the time being, the DPs who still remained in the Bergen-Belsen DP camp were mostly Jews from Poland and Hungary.
With few exceptions, the Jewish DPs in Bergen-Belsen urgently wanted to leave Europe, but initially there were hardly any opportunities for them to emigrate. They were forced to stay indefinitely in Germany, the country of their relatives’ murderers, and in the immediate vicinity of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp to boot. Because their situation was so uncertain, the DPs did everything in their power to take their lives into their own hands again. They were supported in their efforts by many international relief organisations.

text:
Repatriation after the liberation
During the first few weeks, life in the liberated Bergen-Belsen camp was shaped by the British liberators’ relief efforts. At the same time, repatriation measures for the survivors from Western Europe began.
By the autumn of 1945, the majority of the former prisoners had returned to their home countries. The national committees, which represented the different nationalities among the survivors and were set up shortly after the liberation, helped with the registration and repatriation of the former prisoners.
Around 10,000 non-Jewish Polish citizens and around 10,000 Jews, most of them from Poland and Hungary, remained behind. The Jewish survivors lived at the Displaced Persons camp at the former barracks, many of them for years, awaiting the opportunity to emigrate to other countries.

Entertainment for the Wehrmacht
To distract its soldiers from the perceived monotony and stress of their work, the Wehrmacht had a cinema built in Bergen-Belsen with a tavern attached to it. Other taverns were located in the canteens of the service huts (“Wirtschaftsbarracken” or W.B.). Both the cinema and the taverns were run by civilians.
The Wehrmacht hoped to maintain the soldiers' morale by screening the latest films and offering them a selection of luxury goods such as cigarettes and alcohol.

Propaganda for the Wehrmacht
Right from the start, the Wehrmacht ensured that its soldiers in the Bergen-Belsen barracks received ideological instruction. The cinema building, which was erected in 1937, was also used as a lecture hall for ideological training.
When the war against the Soviet Union began, the Wehrmacht intensified its propaganda against Red Army soldiers and Bolshevism. By emphasising the enemy’s way of fighting, the Wehrmacht aimed to justify its own approach and encourage soldiers who came into contact with Soviet POWs to treat them harshly.

They also exact revenge and kill former prisoner functionaries.

text:
Prisoner functionaries in the annex camp
The SS assigned certain functionary positions to individual, mostly German-speaking prisoners. They were appointed as so-called kapos, camp elders, block elders or barrack-room elders. This meant they received better rations, clothing and housing. Their positions gave them the power to exert violence against other prisoners but also to help their fellow prisoners. It is estimated that around 100 prisoner functionaries from the Mittelbau camp complex were lynched by other former prisoners after the liberation of the Bergen-Belsen barracks camp. They were laid to rest in the cemetery behind building M.B. 90.

text:
The liberation and initial aid measures
On 15 April 1945, following a local cease-fire agreement, the SS and Wehrmacht handed over the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp to the British Army without a fight.
The British soldiers were not prepared for what they found when they arrived. There were around 38,000 starving, severely ill and dying people in the main camp. Thousands of bodies were lying in the huts and grounds of the camp. In the annex camp in the barracks, roughly 15,000 survivors were in urgent need of food and medical care.
The British soldiers also had to prevent looting and lynching and arrest perpetrators.
The British immediately called for medical and supply units, and within a short period of time around 3,000 British soldiers, the Red Cross and other humanitarian organizations were on site to care for the liberated prisoners.

text:
Sick quarters in the barracks camp
Building M.B. 90 in the barracks camp of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp was used as sick quarters. Sick and exhausted prisoners received rudimentary aid here from their fellow prisoners. The SS made no effort to offer medical care and provided no supplies, even though these were available in the barracks.
Belgian survivor Maurice Herman kept a list of the prisoners who were cared for in M.B. 90. This list included dates of death.
Directly behind building M.B. 90, the SS established a cemetery for prisoners who had died in the barracks camp.

text:
Memorial culture
The building known as M.B. 90 was used as a hospital in the Bergen-Belsen barracks camp. Prisoners who died in this block were buried nearby.
Prisoner functionaries (kapos) who had been lynched by their fellow prisoners after the liberation were also buried there. On 13 March 1952, Alfred Kurzke, a former camp doctor in Mittelbau-Dora, described the lynching:
"Just a few hours after the camp was taken over by English troops, various kapos along with foremen and members of the camp guards were called to account and murdered by other prisoners for their previous brutalities. […] These dead prisoners […] were […] buried in several graves behind Block 90."
Based on this statement, the graves behind M.B. 90 were referred to for decades as the Kapo Cemetery. However, statements from survivors indicate that prisoners who were not in functionary roles were also laid to rest behind M.B. 90. It is estimated that more than 100 people were buried there.

The majority of the liberated Jews were young adults, and they often were the only members of their families who had survived. After liberation they were confronted with their terrible losses and had to face an uncertain future.

text:
The Bergen-Belsen Displaced Persons Camp 1945-1950
After their liberation by the British Army on 15 April 1945, the survivors of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp were taken to the nearby former Wehrmacht barracks, where they received medical care.
The Allies created the legal status of “displaced persons” (DPs) for the former concentration camp prisoners and slave labourers who had been deported to Germany from all over Europe. They were entitled to special support from the Allies.
By the autumn of 1945, the majority of the former prisoners had returned to their home countries. The national committees, which represented the different nationalities among the survivors and were set up shortly after the liberation, helped with the registration and repatriation of the former prisoners.
Around 10,000 non-Jewish Polish citizens and around 10,000 Jews, most of them from Poland and Hungary, remained behind. The Jewish survivors lived in the Displaced Persons Camp at the former barracks, many of them for years, awaiting the opportunity to emigrate to other countries.

text:
Entertainment in the Bergen-Belsen displaced persons camp
Most residents of the Bergen-Belsen DP camp felt their situation was hopeless. They were forced to live in the camp because they did not want to return to their countries of origin and they had no prospects for emigration. In light of this, they were in urgent need of diversion and occupation, sports and entertainment. Such activities helped the DPs deal with the traumatic events from the time of their imprisonment and enabled them to counter their worries about the future with positive experiences. In both the Polish and Jewish DP camps there were film screenings, musical performances, orchestras, theatre groups and sporting events.
The cinema was used for many of these activities, as well as for political meetings and conferences organised by the displaced persons.

text:
Hilfsmaßnahmen nach der Befreiung
With the front approaching, the Wehrmacht and the SS surrendered Bergen-Belsen concentration camp peacefully to the British army in the context of a local truce and before most of the prisoners had been evacuated. This was done in order to prevent the spread of the epidemics that had broken out in the camp.
The British troops were in no way prepared for the inferno they were confronted with when they arrived at Bergen-Belsen on the afternoon of 15 April 1945.
They immediately implemented relief measures which were continued and intensified over the following days by the medical and supply units they had hurriedly requested. Eventually, around 3,000 British soldiers were deployed to Bergen-Belsen. They were supported by units of the British Red Cross and other relief organisations, as well as by many volunteers. Medication, bandages, food, clothes and all kinds of everyday items had to be brought in for the survivors.

text:
Perpetrators
The Wehrmacht was responsible for housing, feeding and guarding the POW's. The PoWs were guarded by soldiers who could not be deployed to the front because of their age or physical afflications. The camps' headquarters were staffed with reserve officers, many of whom were over 60 years old and had already served in World War I. The guidelines for the conduct towards Soviet POWs issued by the Wehrmacht High Command demanded a ruthless treatment of these prisoners without any respect for martial or international law. Many soldiers acted accordingly, others sometimes used the leeway they had to the to prisoners advantage.

The first guards squads to be deployed at Bergen-Belsen exchange camp came from the recently disbanded Niederhagen concentration camp. Niederhagen's commandant, SS-Sturmbannführer Adolf Haas, became the first commandant of Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. In December 1944, SS-Hauptsturmführer Josef Kramer replaced Haas as commandant. Prior to this, Kramer had been commandant of the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp. He also brought female SS guards to Bergen-Belsen for the first time. Between April 1943 and April 1945, at least 480 SS guards were posted to Bergen-Belsen, among them around 45 female guards.
